My point about language change is that word meanings evolve because people begin to use them differently than their dictionary definitions, or "incorrectly", as linguistic proscriptivists would describe it.
A dictionary documents current usage but is not the "authority" on the meanings of words. Speakers of a language determine the meanings of words and dictionaries record these meanings. Depending on the context a speaker may stipulate the meaning of a term.
Acceptable use ultimatley is determined by convention. "Inflammable" has been replaced by "flammable", a word that would have seemed awkward in the past but is now on many product labels. Apparently, it is an acceptable word!
Etymology may provide a history of the meanings of a word, but past meanings do not commit the user to perpetuating them. One need not know the Latin roots of a word to use it correctly, now, interesting tidbit that it may be.
The denial that there is an "inherent meaning" is the denial that a word has a "real meaning", independent from that understood by consensus. "Dilapidated" would be a good example. A good bet would be that every reader of this column understands what it is for a building to be dilapitated and also that few understand this to involve only buildings composed of stone.
There is no "inherent meaning" derived from the word's etymology that can be cited to say, " You are all wrong. Only stone buildings can be dilapitated.

Here's my best hiring story. (It's all been downhill from here!) Back in 1982 I had just quit my very first job after college, following 2 years' employment in the glorified sweatshop that it was.
I had very little money and so I was sitting on a wall in the middle of the city, eating my bagel from home, people watching. I was wearing sandals and sloppy cut-off jeans. A woman in business attire who had walked by on her way for take-out was making her return to the building next to the wall I was sitting on. She struck up a brief conversation with me about the weather, which was finally nice. In the course of chatting, I told her that I was enjoying the wonderful day despite not having a job at the moment. One thing led to the other, and it turned out she was one of 4 people who had recently started up a small business in the same general business as the job I had recently quit. She said they needed someone else to do the lower-level work and would I come upstairs and meet the other 3 people? I mentioned my sloppy attire and she said not to worry, she'd explain. An hour later I had the job, and and I worked there for about a year and gained a ton of valuable experience, and they in turn valued my work ethic.
I miss those days. The sad thing is, I'm not making much more per hour than I was then despite decades of experience.
Ain't capitalism great.

Let me tell you what job hunting used to be like...back in the fifties.

I was discharged from the Navy in January of 1957 after 4 years as a junior officer serving on two ships that spent a great deal of time at sea. I arrived home on a Wednesday afternoon. My wife, my 18-month old son, and I were delirious with joy knowing we had a whole life to be together without the separations common to military life. The next day (Thursday) I took a bus into the city and walked into the regional IBM sales office. I told the receptionist I was looking for a job. She called her boss who, after a few minutes of sizing me up, gave me a 30-minute test; three parts, 10 minutes to do each part. The test was scored and I was invited to meet the regional vice president of sales for a personal interview the very next day (Friday). I shared about an hour with this man discussing my academic experience, my naval assignments, and my life goals. At the end of the interview I was offered a sales trainee job starting on the following Monday. That's how I became a part of the information technology boom and spent the next 40 years making a ton of money.

Job hunting was different back then. You didn't have to waste time convincing a functionary (HR drone) that you had a future.

It has nothing to do with perfectionism - we can all tell from the ads that they're trying to lower wage expectations. Many businesses want "3-5 years of experience" for positions that pay less than one dollar over minimum wage - for say, a paralegal who greets people at the front desk, cleans the bathroom and does the accounting.

One job I got last fall had twenty-five people sit around AFTER hire and be "re-tested" with ten questions every four days - with no work in between. In the meantime we were told to "look busy". As it turned out, it was because the just-outta-college low-wage "supervisors" had no idea how to manage the project, just how to look upbeat & say "no problem!" This "re-testing" with no work went on for months, while the project languished, until only ten people were left.
The remainder were all over 35 (no smartphones, so we "looked busy") and were treated as if we'd never seen a computer before. Then we were told the project was behind because we didn't do enough keystrokes (on a click&point assignment) and that we must turn off our phones (causing consternation among the parents) since obviously we must be busy playing games, and we must never look up from our screens, or talk to our coworkers about the work, and that "your butt should never leave the chair". Needless to say, our old butts knew workplace law, and that there were better low-wage jobs out there...

I've had your experience not once, not twice, but at least 4-5 times. One interview process lasted 7 interviews, and went on for over six months, winnowing about 100 candidates down to 3. I didn't get the job of course, But neither did anyone else. They decided in the end, after what must have cost a fortune of time and manpower (not to mention the individual costs of the unfortunate interviewees), that they just didn't want anyone in the position. Nobody was "good enough".

The theme is casual disrespect of the potential employee. it's been this way for years. Every Supreme Court ruling in the last 30 years makes it harder for an average person to vote, get or keep a job, get paid a living wage, etc, etc, etc.

In the 90s I interviewed at an insurance company 3 times. Each session included a meeting with at least 2 other people. I was one of two people left in the running and then..nothing.

After finally reaching the previously very pleasant and responsive HR person (who works out of a centralized location), his attitude was dismissive and annoyed. He reluctantly told me they did not actually hire anyone for the position,

And how much time did they waste? My hours, the hours of the poor saps who were also vying for the job, as well as the multitudes of managers who talk with this person they will never actually work with or see again....

It's OK in our culture to dis the 99%, or 47% or whomever isn't as fortunate or well-employed. This type of behavior, which is classless and rude, is how our overlords treat us. They don't HAVE to do anything else, and we know they WON'T do the right thing unless the feds make them.

Then they'll whine about an overreaching government and too much bureaucracy. It's their own fault. This is the one slice of a dynamic which includes the environment, taxation and every aspect of the corporate organism in our society.

Revoke the corporate charters. Make them responsible citizens, just like the rest of us.

Sen. Paul has gone on record as being critical of the drone policy, including the policy employed by the Bush administration.  It's a non-partisan argument.
Drones are already being used on the borders.

I'd like to think that Sen. Paul is making a noble stand in defense of a solemn principle. But he's a Washington politician with one eye always on fundraising. And his libertarian philosophy doesn't extend to women's rights regarding their own bodies. So I'm a little skeptical.

The question about use of drones and extra-judicial killing is a worthwhile issue. There are certainly circumstances (e.g. self-defense, imminent danger) under which no one would criticize the use of such force and circumstances under which the use would be condemned (if we, as citizens, were made aware of the killing). And it is prudent to either fit the use under current law or to develop a new law.

But as soon as another 9/11 type event happens or a Republican takes over the White House, I'm not sure that Sen. Paul might not find an acceptable exception to the law. In fact, I'd be surprised if, in the next Republican Presidential primary debates, the idea of using drones to protect our borders didn't come up.
